Award.AwardTitle: Student Support: 15th IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering (IEEE CASE 2019); Vancouver, Canada; 22-26 August 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides support for graduate students to participate in the IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering in Vancouver, Canada, in August 2019. Students from the operations engineering community will be able to present papers and participate in many sessions highly relevant to their research areas, including data science, fault detection, diagnosis and prognostics, modeling and simulation of automated systems, smart factories, logistics and supply chains. Attending this conference will give students the chance to present their work and interact with other scholars to strengthen the academic community and industrial base in addressing critical needs in automation science. By providing travel and subsistence funds, this award will help remove barriers to attendance and broaden participation among underrepresented communities in engineering, thus developing a diverse set of future researchers.

The IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering is the premier international conference for academics and practitioners who are addressing challenges and opportunities in the field of automation science and engineering. The conference attracts many academic engineering researchers, especially those addressing critical societal needs in data science to support automated manufacturing and logistics systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this conference participation proposal is to support the attendance of 10 underrepresented operations engineering students from U.S. educational institutions to present their research at the 15th IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering  (IEEE CASE 2019) held on August 22-26, 2019, in Vancouver, Canada. Ten underrepresented students from US institutions were selected and participated in the conference. They attended technical presentations by the leading international experts in the broad field of operations engineering, met with senior and peer researchers from multiple disciplines around the world. These experiences help them to learn about the latest research progress and challenges in operations engineering, and to present papers they co-authored. They will have the opportunity to practice their communication skills and network with researchers and engineers from the U.S. and around the world, fostering new ideas and future collaborations in their research, deep their understanding, and shape their future careers in operations engineering. Moreover, the social activities helped them to meet with conference leaders, gathered with other junior researchers, and joined the women in engineering forum. This conference experience will be invaluable for these highly talented underrepresented group of students who, as future operations engineering professionals and academic researchers, will drive U.S. efforts to ensure its competitiveness to improve operations.

  

 


Last Modified: 04/13/2020
Modified by: Jingshan Li
